explanation: Scholar's Mate: White's queen captures f7 with checkmate. Black failed to defend the f7 pawn after Bc4 and Qh5.
Fried Liver Attack preparation: Ng5 targets the weak f7 square. After 4...d5 5.exd5 Nxd5 6.Nxf7! sacrifices the knight for a devastating attack on the exposed king.
Fishing Pole Trap setup in Ruy Lopez: Black plays ...f5, inviting exf5 which opens lines against the white king. A common beginner trap that punishes greedy pawn grabbing.
King's Gambit trap: After 1.e4 e5 2.f4, Black plays Qh4+ giving check. White's king is exposed after f4 weakened the kingside. White cannot castle and the queen is very active.
Fool's Mate: After 1.f3 e5 2.g4, Black delivers checkmate with Qh4#. The fastest possible checkmate in chess.
Legal's Mate preparation: In the Italian Game after d4, Black captures exd4. If Black gets greedy with ...Bxf2+, White can sacrifice the queen and deliver checkmate with the minor pieces.
Englund Gambit Trap avoidance: The principled response to 1.e4 is 1...e5, controlling the center. Gambits like 1...e6 or 1...b6 can lead to traps for the unprepared.
King's Gambit Accepted trap: After 1.e4 e5 2.f4 exf4 3.Bc4??, Black plays Qh4+ with a powerful check. White's king is exposed and the position is very difficult to defend.
French Defense: Advance Variation. Black plays c5 to challenge White's pawn center. Failing to play c5 lets White build an overwhelming space advantage.
Budapest Gambit: After 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4, Black plays e5!? sacrificing a pawn for rapid development and tactical chances. White must be careful not to fall into the Kieninger Trap.
In the Nimzo-Indian Defense: Classical Variation, Zurich Variation (E33), the natural-looking Qg6 is a mistake (loses ~780cp). The correct move is Nf3.
In the French Defense: Tarrasch Variation (C03), the natural-looking Bc5 is a mistake (loses ~393cp). The correct move is c5.
In the Four Knights Game: Scotch Variation (C47), the natural-looking Rg8 is a mistake (loses ~241cp). The correct move is exd4.
In the Nimzowitsch Defense: Neo-Mongoloid Defense (B00), the natural-looking Qf3 is a mistake (loses ~234cp). The correct move is Nf3.
In the Bishop's Opening: Boden-Kieseritzky Gambit (C27), the natural-looking h5 is a mistake (loses ~324cp). The correct move is Nxc3.
In the Ware Opening: Wing Gambit (A00), the natural-looking Rxa7 is a mistake (loses ~512cp). The correct move is Nf3.
In the Caro-Kann Defense (B15), the natural-looking f4 is a mistake (loses ~203cp). The correct move is Nxe4.
In the Sicilian Defense: Smith-Morra Gambit Accepted (B21), the natural-looking Qd4 is a mistake (loses ~151cp). The correct move is Nxc3.
In the Center Game: Hall Variation (C22), the natural-looking f6 is a mistake (loses ~165cp). The correct move is Nf6.
In the Nimzo-Indian Defense: Romanishin Variation (E20), the natural-looking Bc5 is a mistake (loses ~465cp). The correct move is O-O.
In the English Opening: Anglo-Dutch Variation, Chabanon Gambit (A10), the natural-looking g5 is a mistake (loses ~200cp). The correct move is fxe4.
In the Blackmar-Diemer Gambit Declined: Elbert Countergambit (D00), the natural-looking Bg5 is a mistake (loses ~249cp). The correct move is dxe5.
In the Ruy Lopez: Pollock Defense (C60), the natural-looking Rg1 is a mistake (loses ~168cp). The correct move is c3.
In the Tarrasch Defense (D32), the natural-looking Qd3 is a mistake (loses ~241cp). The correct move is cxd5.
In the Englund Gambit Declined: Reversed French (A40), the natural-looking Qh4 is a mistake (loses ~173cp). The correct move is exd4.
In the Vienna Game: Vienna Gambit, Main Line (C29), the natural-looking Ba6 is a mistake (loses ~451cp). The correct move is fxe5.
In the Pterodactyl Defense: Fianchetto, Rhamphorhynchus (B06), the natural-looking b4 is a mistake (loses ~458cp). The correct move is c3.
In the Ruy Lopez: Berlin Defense, Fishing Pole Variation (C65), the natural-looking Nh4 is a mistake (loses ~522cp). The correct move is h3.
In the Sicilian Defense: O'Kelly Variation, Venice System, Ljubojevic Line (B28), the natural-looking Nd4 is a mistake (loses ~468cp). The correct move is d4.
In the Van Geet Opening: Reversed Scandinavian (A00), the natural-looking Na5 is a mistake (loses ~485cp). The correct move is Nf6.
